FINAL REPORT
 ABDOMEN ULTRASOUND

 HISTORY:  81-year-old woman with GIB, colon demonstrates evidence of chronic
 colonic ischemia, please do Doppler ultrasound.

 There is no biliary duct dilatation.  CBD measures 4 mm.  The pancreas is
 unremarkable.  Both kidneys are normal in size, and echogenic without

 9.4 cm.

 assessment shows normal spectral flow and velocities within normal limits.
 There is no spectral broadening.

 There is a small right pleural effusion.

question: What is the placement of ETT?
context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: Reintubated.

 tube tip is in satisfactory position, 2 cm above the carina.  There is no
 change in the position of the left IJ central venous catheter; the nasogastric
 tube tip has been advanced more distally, and is not included in the film,
 presumably at least as far as the duodenum.

 interval worsening in the left upper chest peripherally, where a sizable
 density with  air bronchograms is noted.  The remaining infiltrates are
 without definite change.

question: Are there any abnormalities on left chest wall?
labels:
evidence of healed rib fractures on the left side of [**Doctor Last Name **] 5 and 6 appear
 unchanged.  A surgical clip is noted in the vicinity of the rib fracture
context:
FINAL REPORT
 TYPE OF EXAMINATION:  Chest PA and lateral.

 INDICATION:  History of implanted vagal nerve stimulator implantation.  The
 patient has left-sided chest pain.  Evaluate thorax and lungs.

 FINDINGS:  PA and lateral chest view demonstrates the presence of an
 electronic capsule in left anterior chest wall position.  Thin wire electrodes
 are noted in the anterior chest wall and lead to electrode termination points
 in the left-sided paravertebral space at level Th1 and Th2.  Apparently, this
 represents the vagal nerve stimulator.  The skeletal structures of the thorax
 are unremarkable.  The heart size is within normal limits.  Thoracic aorta and
 mediastinal structures are unremarkable.  The pulmonary vasculature is normal,
 and the lateral and posterior pleural sinuses are free.  No acute parenchymal
 infiltrates can be identified.  Available for comparison is a similar previous
 chest examination dated [**2100-12-15**].  At that time, present right
 internal jugular vein central venous line has been removed.  As before,
 evidence of healed rib fractures on the left side of [**Doctor Last Name **] 5 and 6 appear
 unchanged.  A surgical clip is noted in the vicinity of the rib fracture
 raising the suspicion that this injury was related to a previous surgical
 intervention.

 On the lateral view, calcifications within the aortic valve area are
 identified.  They appear to have three components and thus rather typical for
 aortic valve stenosis involving all the three cusps.  Comparison with the next
 previous chest examination of [**2100-12-15**], confirms the presence of these
 calcifications.  The heart is not significantly enlarged and there is no
 evidence of CHF.  No evidence of significant poststenotic dilatation of the
 ascending aorta on the frontal view.

question: Are there any pulmonary infiltrates?
labels:
Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities and numerous smoothly
 thickened septal lines
context:
IMPRESSION:  1)  Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities and numerous smoothly
 thickened septal lines.  In a patient with history of CHF, these findings may
 reflect hydrostatic pulmonary edema.  It is difficult to fully exclude the
 possibility of amiodarone lung toxicity, but the absence of significant
 hyperdensity in the liver would make amiodarone lung toxicity unusual (usually
 patient's with significant doses of amiodarone will demonstrate high density
 livers on CT scan).  If the diagnosis remains in doubt clinically, consider a
 follow up high resolution CT after vigorous diuresis.
 2)  Moderate sized bilateral pleural effusions which are freely layering on
 prone images.
 3)  Mildly enlarged mediastinal lymph nodes, which can be seen in the setting
 of CHF, but are non-specific.
 4) Small bilateral calcified pleural plaques, suggestive of previous asbestos
 exposure.
 5) Low density right adrenal lesion suggestive of adenoma.

 smoothly thickened septal lines.  The ground-glass opacities are patchy and
 diffuse in distribution but most pronounced in the upper lobes.  No areas of

 significant improvement with changes in positioning of the patient with

context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Abnormal pulmonary function test.  Dyspnea with minimal exertion.
  Clinical suspicion for amiodarone lung toxicity.  History of CHF.

 Helical and high resolution CT imaging of the chest were performed without IV
 or oral contrast administration.  High resolution CT images were obtained with
 1 mm collimation at 2 cm intervals throughout the thorax in both the prone and
 supine positions.  Additionally, three expiratory images were obtained.

 Assessment of the lungs reveals diffuse ground-glass opacities and numerous
 smoothly thickened septal lines.  The ground-glass opacities are patchy and
 diffuse in distribution but most pronounced in the upper lobes.  No areas of
 honeycombing or architectural distortion are identified.  Moderate sized
 dependent bilateral pleural effusions are identified and demonstrate layering
 on prone images.  Adjacent areas of atelectasis in the lung bases show
 significant improvement with changes in positioning of the patient with
 minimal atelectatic changes remaining predominantly posteromedially at the
 bases.

 Assessment of the lungs on helical CT acquisition show scattered linear
 opacities suggestive of discoid atelectasis or scar in the middle lobe and
 lingula.  The ground-glass opacities are again demonstrated on these images.
 Assessment of the central airways reveals a focal polypoid lesion in the
 lateral wall of the trachea posteriorly at the level just above the aortic
 arch, probably due to retained secretions.

 Assessment of the soft tissue structures of the thorax reveals several lymph
 nodes in the mediastinum in the prevascular and paratracheal regions.  The
 largest lymph node is in the lower right paratracheal region, measures
 approximately 11 mm in short axis dimension, and has a prominent fatty center.
  No significant hilar lymph node enlargement is observed on this non-contrast
 study.  The heart is upper limits of normal in size.  Coronary artery
 calcifications are noted.  No pericardial effusion is evident.

 Imaging of the upper portion of the abdomen demonstrates no significant
 abnormality within the imaged portion of the liver or spleen, but these organs
 are incompletely imaged on this study.  The spleen appears somewhat prominent
 but size cannot be determined as it is not completely imaged on this study.
 There is a focal well-circumscribed low density lesion in the right adrenal
 gland suggestive of adenoma.  There is also focal thickening of the left
 adrenal gland.  The imaged portion of the pancreas is unremarkable.

 Vascular calcifications are observed in the aorta and in the abdominal aortic
 branches.

 The osseous structures of the thorax demonstrate degenerative changes in the
 spine and evidence of previous sternotomy procedure.  Finally, note is made of
 bilateral calcified pleural plaques.

question: Is there any evidence of bleeding in the chest cavity?
context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: Patient is status post percutaneous catheter ablation of AV node
 with an acute blood loss without evidence of abdominal bleed, GI bleed,
 or thigh bleed, CT of abdomen and pelvis was unrevealing for source of GI
 bleed and consequently the chest is to be evaluated for bleed.

 COMPARISONS: [**2155-8-7**] CT of abdomen and pelvis was used for comparison.

 TECHNIQUE: CT of the chest and abdomen with IV contrast per aortic CTA
 protocol. 150 cc of Optiray was utilized. Optiray was selected secondary for
 need for fast bolus.

 FINDINGS:

 CT OF THE CHEST WITH IV CONTRAST: There is good opacification of the thoracic
 and abdominal aorta. No intimal flaps are seen to suggest an aortic
 dissection. Additionally there is no evidence of mediastinal hematoma. There
 are very small bilateral low density pleural effusions with associated
 atelectasis. Although this was not performed as a pulmonary CTA there are no
 large, central thrombi within the pulmonary arterial vessels. In the region of
 the subsegmental branch in the right lower lobe there is a suggestion of
 filling defect that is of uncertain significance. No additional filling
 defects are seen within the basilar and pulmonary arteries. There is no
 evidence of a pericardial effusion and additionally there is no evidence of a
 thoracic or abdominal aorta. There is atelectasis primarily involving the
 bases as well as scarring of the right middle lobe.

 CT OF THE ABDOMEN WITH IV CONTRAST: The liver, spleen, pancreas, gallbladder,
 and kidneys are unremarkable. Once again seen is a right adrenal adenoma.
 There is extensive calcification of the abdominal aorta and its tributaries.

 There is colonic diverticulosis without evidence of diverticulitis.

 BONE WINDOWS: There is subchondral cysts of the right scapula. There are
 multilevel degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.

 Incidental note is made of a splenule adjacent to the spleen.

context:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  81-year-old woman with left lower leg ischemia.

 FINDINGS/TECHNIQUE:  Grayscale ultrasound of the right greater saphenous vein
 and right lesser saphenous vein as well as the color duplex of the right
 greater saphenous vein were performed.  The mid portion of the greater
 saphenous vein was not visualized consistent with a history of harvesting.
 Proximal 2.6 cm of the right greater saphenous vein were patent and
 demonstrated diameters of 0.31 and 0.22.  The distal portion of the right
 greater saphenous vein was questionably visualized and showed diameters of
 0.05 and 0.09 cm.  The right lesser saphenous vein was small but patent and
 measured diameters of 0.06, 0.08, and 0.09 cm.

 Doppler evaluation of the arteries of the lower extremities demonstrated
 uniformity monophasic waveform at all levels bilaterally including femoral,
 popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis levels.

 Pulse volume recording demonstrated the following amplitudes:

 RIGHT SIDE:  Low thigh 15 mm, calf 16 mm, ankle 15 mm, and metatarsal 8 mm.

 LEFT SIDE:  Low thigh 16 mm, calf 21 mm, ankle 14 mm, and metatarsal 4 mm.

 Segmental limb pressures in the lower extremities were compared to the
 pressure in the left brachial artery measuring 206 mmHg.  Segmental limb
 pressures in the right lower extremities were as follows:

 RIGHT SIDE:  Low thigh 255 mmHg noncompressible, calf 192 mmHg, posterior
 tibial 116 mmHg, and dorsalis pedis 201 mmHg.

 LEFT SIDE:  Low thigh 255 mmHg, calf 143 mmHg, posterior tibial 52 mmHg, and
 dorsalis pedis 62 mmHg.  Ankle brachial index on the right was 0.98.  Ankle
 brachial index on the left was 0.3.

question: Do we see any neck mass obstructing the course of RLN?
labels: no sign of mass lesion or mass effect along the course
context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION: Left vocal cord paralysis. Assess the course of the recurrent
 laryngeal nerve.

 COMPARISON: None.

 TECHNIQUE: Contrast-enhanced CT of the neck from the level of the main
 pulmonary artery to the posterior fossa. 100 cc of Optiray was used.

 There is no sign of mass lesion or mass effect along the course of the
 left recurrent laryngeal nerve. No lymphadenopathy is identified. There is
 slight asymmetry of the left vocal fold at the level of the true cords without
 evidence of discrete mass. The pharyngeal soft tissues are symmetrical. The
 parapharyngeal fat planes are preserved. The thyroid gland is unremarkable.

 BONE WINDOWS: Degenerative changes are seen in the cervical and upper thoracic
 spine. There are no suspicious lytic or sclerotic bony lesions.

 LUNG WINDOWS: Ground glass opacities are seen peripherally within both lung
 apices with associated consolidation and apparent bronchiectasis. This is
 consistent with the patient's known diagnosis of pneumocystis pneumonia.

 Left internal jugular central venous line is present.

question: Was the PICC line placement procedure easy?
labels:
As no suitable superficial veins were identified, ultrasound
 examination of the left upper extremity was performed, revealing the left
 brachial vein to be patent and compressible.  The area was prepped and draped
 in the usual sterile fashion.  Local anesthesia was achieved with subcutaneous
 injection of 3 cc of 1% lidocaine.  Under real time ultrasound guidance, the
 left brachial vein was accessed using a 21 gauge micropuncture needle.  Hard
 copy pre- and post-puncture images were obtained with ultrasound.  A 0.018
 guidewire was then advanced through the needle and into the SVC under
 fluoroscopic guidance.  Based on the markers on the guidewire, the PICC was
 trimmed to a length of 42 cm.  The needle was then exchanged for an introducer
 sheath.  The PICC was then advanced over the wire through the sheath.  The
 peel-away sheath and wire were then removed.  The catheter was then aspirated,
 flushed, capped, and heplocked.  The line was then secured with a Statlock
 device and a sterile transparent dressing applied.  A final limited chest
 radiograph confirmed placement of the tip of the catheter to be in the distal
 SVC
context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Peripheral vascular disease, upper extremity edema, need for IV
 access, right arm being preserved for veins to harvest.

 PROCEDURE/FINDINGS:  The procedure was performed by doctors [**Name5 (PTitle) 6365**] and
 [**Name5 (PTitle) 109**], the attending radiologist, who was present and supervising throughout
 the procedure.  As no suitable superficial veins were identified, ultrasound
 examination of the left upper extremity was performed, revealing the left

 peel-away sheath and wire were then removed.  The catheter was then aspirated,
 flushed, capped, and heplocked.  The line was then secured with a Statlock
 device and a sterile transparent dressing applied.  A final limited chest
 radiograph confirmed placement of the tip of the catheter to be in the distal
 SVC.  There were no immediate post-procedure complications.  The line is ready
 for use.

 apparent improvement.

question: Was the cholecystomy tube placed correctly?
labels: catheter ends in the gallbladder fundus
context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  History of alcoholic cirrhosis presenting with a perforated
 gallbladder, status post percutaneous cholecystostomy.  Evaluate for evidence
 of a fistula tract.

 proximal portion of the cystic duct is noted, although there is no evidence of
 drainage beyond this point during the approximately 15 minutes of study time.
 The percutaneous cholecystostomy catheter ends in the gallbladder fundus.  A
 dropped gallstone is seen overlying the right abdomen.

question: Was the ETT placed correctly?
context:
FINAL REPORT
 PORTABLE CHEST:

 Compared to previous study of 1 day earlier.

 INDICATION: ETT placement. This radiograph is from 2:40 a.m. on [**2184-2-17**].

 An ETT is in place, and terminates near the carina. A left PICC line

 ground glass pattern with more confluent areas of consolidation at the bases.

question: Does the brain show any abnormal masses with different architecture?
labels:
large area of
 intraparenchymal hemorrhage within the right parietal lobe and left thalamus
 which following administration of gadolinium reveals ring-enhancing lesions.
 These are suspicious for hemorrhagic metastases given the patient's history.
 Additional ring-enhancing lesions throughout the supra- and infratentorial
 compartments are visualized
context:
FINAL REPORT
 EXAMINATION:  MRI of the brain with and without gadolinium.

 INDICATION:  [**Age over 90 **] year old woman with lung cancer and right intracranial bleed
 and history of brain metastases.  Please evaluate for acute infarct.

 TECHNIQUE:  Multiplanar T1 and T2-weighted images of the brain with gadolinium
 according to standard departmental protocol.  No prior study for comparison.

 FINDINGS:  On diffusion-weighted images there is a small area of restricted
 diffusion along the falx within the left occipitotemporal lobe.  It is also
 bright on FLAIR-weighted images and may represent a subacute infarct. Clinical
 correlation is recommended.  On gradient echo images there is a large area of
 intraparenchymal hemorrhage within the right parietal lobe and left thalamus
 which following administration of gadolinium reveals ring-enhancing lesions.
 These are suspicious for hemorrhagic metastases given the patient's history.
 Additional ring-enhancing lesions throughout the supra- and infratentorial
 compartments are visualized.  There is a moderate amount of peritumoral edema
 involving the right parietal lobe lesion in addition to a second right
 parietal lesion along the falx high in the vertex.  The other areas of
 metastases reveal a minimal amount of peritumoral edema.

question: Do we see any blocks in the coronary arteries?
context:
FINAL REPORT
 HISTORY:  Seventy-four year old man with coronary artery disease, post CABG, to
 have electrophysiologic study and possible ablation.

 SUMMARY OF EXERCISE DATA FROM THE REPORT OF THE EXERCISE LAB:
 Dipyridamole was infused for approximately 4 minutes at 0.142 mg/kg/min.  No
 anginal symptoms or ischemic electrocardiographic changes were reported.

 INTERPRETATION:  One to three minutes after the cessation of infusion,
 MIBI was administered IV.
 Image Protocol: Gated SPECT.
 Resting perfusion images were obtained with thallium.
 Tracer was injected 15 minutes prior to obtaining the resting images.

 Stress and resting perfusion images show no myocardial perfusion defects.
 The left ventricular ejection fraction is calculated to be approximately 56%.

 Compared to the study of [**2153-11-8**], there is no significant change.

question: Is fluid collection present?
labels: 2.4 x 3.7 x 20 cm collection in the midline
context:
IMPRESSION:
 1.  2.4 x 3.7 x 20 cm collection in the midline extending from the pelvis to
 the mid abdomen at the incisional site.  This may represent abdominal wall
 hematoma, or alternatively a contained hematoma just deep to the abdominal
 wall where previously large varices had been seen.  The possibility that this
 represents a very distended thrombosed varix is considered, though the overall
 ultrasound appearance is more suggestive of a hematoma.  Since the
 relationship of the drain to this collection cannot be ascertained due to
 bandage material, CT could be obtained for further assessment.
 2.  Scar tissue and tiny amount of fluid within the gallbladder fossa, but no
 organized collection identified.
 3.  Findings consistent with cirrhosis, with splenomegaly and recanalized
 paraumbilical vein.

 Results were discussed with [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) **] at the time of dictation, approximately
 4:00 p.m. on [**2153-6-4**], by Dr. [**First Name (STitle) **] via telephone.

question: Is fluid collection present?
context:
FINAL REPORT
 INDICATION:  Status post subtotal cholecystectomy, now with increasing drain
 output.  Evaluate for fluid collection.

 COMPARISON:  Abdominal ultrasound of [**2153-5-27**].

 TECHNIQUE:  Abdominal ultrasound.

 FINDINGS:  The study is again technically limited due to surgical incisions,
 and the presence of bandage material.  The liver is diffusely coarse and
 nodular consistent with cirrhosis.  A focal tiny amount of fluid is seen in
 the subhepatic space adjacent to the falciform ligament and gallbladder fossa.
 Some additional hypoechogenicity within this region most likely reflects
 post-surgical changes in the resection bed.  There is no intra- or
 extra-hepatic biliary ductal dilation with the common hepatic duct measuring 3
 mm.  The portal vein is patent with antegrade flow.  Spleen remains enlarged
 measuring 14.9 cm.  A tubular structure within the falciform ligament is also
 again seen, which does not demonstrate internal flow, but may represent a
 portion of the patient's recanalized paraumbilical vein with markedly slow
 flow.

 Targeted son[**Name (NI) 211**] imaging of the region adjacent to the obliquely oriented
 surgical incision, shows an oblong fluid collection which measures 2.4 x 3.7
 cm in the transverse plane and spans from mid abdomen to low pelvis, measuring
 at least 20 cm in the SI dimension.  This is lobulated and heterogeneously
 hypoechoic and probably located within or just deep to the abdominal wall
 musculature, and is felt most likely to represent a hematoma.  A surgical
 drain enters the right lower quadrant, but the tip of the drain could not be
 detected due to the presence of overlying bandage material, so its
 relationship to this collection is not ascertained.

 and the presence of bandage material.  The liver is diffusely coarse and
 nodular consistent with cirrhosis.  A focal tiny amount of fluid is seen in
 the subhepatic space adjacent to the falciform ligament and gallbladder fossa.

 post-surgical changes in the resection bed.  There is no intra- or
 extra-hepatic biliary ductal dilation with the common hepatic duct measuring 3
 mm.  The portal vein is patent with antegrade flow.  Spleen remains enlarged
 measuring 14.9 cm.  A tubular structure within the falciform ligament is also
 again seen, which does not demonstrate internal flow, but may represent a
 portion of the patient's recanalized paraumbilical vein with markedly slow
 flow.

 Targeted son[**Name (NI) 211**] imaging of the region adjacent to the obliquely oriented
 surgical incision, shows an oblong fluid collection which measures 2.4 x 3.7
 cm in the transverse plane and spans from mid abdomen to low pelvis, measuring
 at least 20 cm in the SI dimension.  This is lobulated and heterogeneously
 hypoechoic and probably located within or just deep to the abdominal wall
 musculature, and is felt most likely to represent a hematoma.  A surgical
 drain enters the right lower quadrant, but the tip of the drain could not be
 detected due to the presence of overlying bandage material, so its
 relationship to this collection is not ascertained.
